original_text: Before you get started, take a minute to review the fundamental terms and concepts pertaining to pruning. [substeps] Shearing is the act of maintenance where you simply trim the outermost layers of foliage or growth on a plant to maintain its shape and size. This is often done with hedge plants or topiaries. Thinning is the process of removing some of the interior branches and growth to improve the health and structure of the plant. This can be done to improve air circulation or to reduce the likelihood of disease or pest infestation. Heading back is the action of cutting back the tips of branches to stimulate new growth and shape the plant. This is commonly done on trees and shrubs to promote bushier growth. Deadheading is the practice of removing spent blooms from a plant to encourage more flowers to grow. Pruning can be done at different times of the year depending on the type of plant and its growth cycle. Late winter or early spring is often a good time for pruning deciduous trees and shrubs, while evergreens can be pruned in late spring or early summer. It is important to use sharp, clean tools and to make cuts at a 45-degree angle to promote quick healing and reduce the risk of damage or disease.
